Package cetus.hir

Class Expression

  • java.lang.Object
    • cetus.hir.Expression
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Printable, Traversable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Comparable<Expression>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AlignofExpression, ArrayAccess, BinaryExpression, CommaExpression, CompoundLiteral, ConditionalExpression, DeleteExpression, FunctionCall, IDExpression, InfExpression, Literal, MinMaxExpression, NewExpression, OffsetofExpression, RangeExpression, SizeofExpression, SomeExpression, StatementExpression, ThrowExpression, Typecast, UnaryExpression, VaArgExpression
    public abstract class Expression
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Comparable<Expression>, Traversable
    Base class for all expressions. Expressions are compared lexically against other expressions when used in collections.

      • equals

        public boolean equals​(java.lang.Object o)
        Checks if the given object is has the same type with this expression and its children is same with this expression's. The sub classes of expression should call this method first and proceed with more checking if they have additional fields to be checked.
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
        Parameters:
        o - the object to be compared with.
        Returns:
        true if o!=null, this.getClass()==o.getClass(), and this.children.equals(o.children) || this.children==o.children==null

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Returns the hash code of the expression. It returns the hash code of the string representation since expressions are compared lexically.
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        the integer hash code of the expression.

      • hashCode

        protected int hashCode​(int h)
        Returns cumulative hash code with the given initial value, h. This is intended for optimizing memory usage when computing hash code of an expression object. Previous approach constructs a string representation of the expression to get the hash code while this approach uses the same algorithm as String.hashCode() without creating a string. All sub classes of Expression have there specific implementations of this method and hashCode() simply returns hashCode(0).

      • findExpression

        public java.util.List<Expression> findExpression​(Expression expr)
        Returns a list of subexpressions of this expression that match expr using its equals method.
        Parameters:
        expr - The subexpression sought.
        Returns:
        a list of matching subexpressions, which may be empty.

      • getChildren

        public java.util.List<Traversable> getChildren()
        Description copied from interface: Traversable
        Provides access to the children of this object as a list. This object is free to internally implement its list as a LinkedList or an ArrayList. It is generally not good practice to call this method yourself; the ordering of children is not guaranteed so instead you should use the methods of the particular class whose children you wish to access.
        Specified by:
        getChildren in interface Traversable
        Returns:
        the children as a list.

      • getParent

        public Traversable getParent()
        Description copied from interface: Traversable
        Provides access to the parent of this object. Every IR object has at most one parent. (The parent relationship is the same as the parent relationship in the parse tree, and is not to be confused with the base class of a derived class declaration.)
        Specified by:
        getParent in interface Traversable
        Returns:
        the parent of this object.

      • getStatement

        public Statement getStatement()
        Get the parent Statement containing this Expression.
        Returns:
        the enclosing Statement or null if this Expression is not inside a Statement.

      • removeChild

        public void removeChild​(Traversable child)
        This operation is not allowed.
        Specified by:
        removeChild in interface Traversable
        Parameters:
        child - a reference to a child object that must match with ==.
        Throws:

      • setChild

        public void setChild​(int index,
                     Traversable t)
        Description copied from interface: Traversable
        Sets the indexth child of this object to t. By calling this method, the old child located at the position i will have a null parent. It is generally not good practice to call this method yourself; the ordering of children is not guaranteed so instead you should use the methods of the particular class whose children you wish to access. There are checks to prevent such actions as making a statement a child of an expression, but you still may be able to do some damage with this method if you are not careful.
        Specified by:
        setChild in interface Traversable
        Throws:
        NotAnOrphanException - if t has a parent object.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if index is out-of-range or t is not an expression.

      • setParens

        public void setParens​(boolean f)
        Sets whether the expression needs to have an outer set of parentheses printed around it.
        Parameters:
        f - True to use parens, false to not use parens.

      • needsParens

        public boolean needsParens()
        Checks if the expression needs parentheses around itself when printed.

      • setParent

        public void setParent​(Traversable t)
        Description copied from interface: Traversable
        Sets the parent of this object. Cetus checks that the parent already considers this object a child. The intent is to maintain an ordering where first this object becomes a child of another object, and then this object is told who its parent is. Enforcing this order makes it easier for Cetus to enforce other invariants and ensure the IR is correct.
        Specified by:
        setParent in interface Traversable

      • setPrintMethod

        public void setPrintMethod​(java.lang.reflect.Method m)
        Overrides the print method for this object only.
        Parameters:
        m - The new print method.

      • swapWith

        public void swapWith​(Expression expr)
        Swaps two expression on the IR tree. If neither this expression nor expr has a parent, then this function has no effect. Otherwise, each expression ends up with the other's parent and exchange positions in the parents' lists of children.
        Parameters:
        expr - The expression with which to swap this expression.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if expr is null.
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the types of the expressions are such that they would create inconsistent IR when swapped.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a string representation of the expression
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • verify

        public void verify()
            throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Verifies three properties of this object: (1) All children are not null, (2) the parent object has this object as a child, (3) all children have this object as the parent.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if any of the properties are not true.
